Posts.Content: MinAZ wrote: My friend had an SNB recently; she had already had a lumpectomy a couple of weeks earlier. The surgeon did not put in a drain and I was surprised because I, and others I know, had drains with SNB. Is it common not to have one? Now she has a seroma in that area and he says it will reabsorb, he does not want to drain it even though it's bothering her. How long does it usually take to reabsorb? Thanks - Minz Dx 10/15/2006, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Drain with SNB? MinAZ emath

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2008 05:25PM MinAZ wrote: Bette Lou - I had a mastectomy and SNB together, so I can't really say how long till you'll feel like going to work. I wouldn't think you'd be going to work while you have a drain - although apparently everyone doesn't get them. And I imagine the kind of work you do might be a factor.   I can tell you the SNB area was tender for several weeks, and it had kind of a burning feeling - nerves regenerating. I could reach over my head right away, but not all gals can do that. Hopfeully some of the other gals can give you more ideas about returning to work after SNB.   MInz

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 08:35PM MinAZ wrote: Shelly - I had my fills completed in early September 07 and had exchange and lift on my 'good' side scheduled for Nov. 7. Then in October a regular mammo on my 'good' side showed some abnormality - I was a basket case for a while, I assure you! I contacted my breast surgeon, and he ordered an immediate biopsy. It turned out OK and my exchange and lift went on as scheduled.  If there had been a problem I would have relied on his guidance depending on just what was wrong. I might have had the exchange as scheduled but not the lift or something. By the way, they had done the tests before the mast last January, but things change. So I would talk to both your breast surgeon and plastic surgeon about it. Best of luck - Minz

Posts.Title: Stage IIIB and IBC? MinAZ MinAZ

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2008 08:34PM MinAZ wrote: I'm not a lymphedema gal (at least not yet, knock on wood) but I use the foam roll mentioned above. I got mine from my trainer way before I had BC.  I use it to work on muscles when they're tight -  shoulders, upper and lower back, buns, thighs, calves - almost everywhere. For legs I do it on the floor but for my back and shoulders I usually use it standing up against the wall, and I kind of move up and down on it. I'm not very graceful, for sure, but it helps. The roll is quite firm and can hurt when the muscle is really tight, so I don't know if that would be a problem for lymphedema . . .  The 36" roll was kind of unwieldy so I cut off a 12" section that I use most of the time. I think I've seen them in sporting goods stores, so you don't need a trainer to get one. Minz

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2009 11:08AM MinAZ wrote: At my hospital you don't get to your room til after the surgery. You start at admissions then you go to pre-op, then surgery and recovery, and finally a room. I think it probably has something to do with insurance. They start the time count for in v. out patient when you get to a room, I believe. The prep and OR time do not count. Here they try to do most mastectomies as out patient - you are in an actual room for less than 24 hours, assuming no complications. Does that make sense? Best of luck.....  Minz

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2007 10:55AM MinAZ wrote: Yes, the odds are in your favor but I know that doesn't stop you from worrying. Sorry I  can't tell you for sure the percentages, but I believe I've read that 80-85% of lumps, etc., are benign. Your situation is exactly what's happening with a friend of mine. She has the test in about 2 weeks and was referred to a surgeon for after the test. I wonder if it's because a surgeon would be more experienced in working with irregularities than a GP? Can you get COBRA so you'll have insurance for a while? Maybe that would get you through some of the medical if you need anything. I was told when I left my company that with COBRA I would not have to worry about pre-exisiting conditions - I was already in BC treatment. I know we will all be sending positive thoughts your way. Best of luck with your test. Minz

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2007 08:24PM MinAZ wrote: I didn't have much pain after the overnight in the hospital. But I did not have an expander inserted at that time, and only two nodes removed, so I imagine that made a difference. I had the ace bandage thing off after five days, but I was afraid to look at the incision. I finally did after two weeks and it really wasn't so bad. When I had the expander put in 6 months later, it was a bit more painful, but still not terrible. I learned to follow advice from these boards - take the pain pills before you think you need them, keeps the pain under control much better.

Can they keep you overnight at the surgery center?  When you add expanders at the same time as mast, it is more to recover from so I'd feel better being in a hospital. Minz

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2008 09:36PM MinAZ wrote: Otter - I was diagnosed in Oct 06 with IDC 1 cm and I absolutely did not want a mastectomy. I was scheduled for the lumpectomy plus a wired-guided biopsy of another area and then things fell apart. I had the biopsy only, and that was ADH. So my surgeon then recommended mastectomy and I had it in January 07. It absolutely was not bad and I am so glad I did it. My only regret is that I did not have the other side done also. Take your time in deciding and then do what feels right for you! Good luck  - Minz

Posts.Title: Why some need chemo after surgery, some not??? Karina Karina

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 04:24PM MinAZ wrote: They take out nodes during SNB. The number varies. I had two removed, one friend had five and another only one. I think it must depend on where the dye shows up. They they do a quick biopsy in the OR and if there is any sign of cancer they take out more nodes. But the final word comes later - they send the tissue out to a lab for more in-depth testing.

Posts.Title: What to bring to the hospital luvmyself shrink

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2008 12:12PM MinAZ wrote: My hospital has an Am. Cancer Society office inside - I volunteer there now that I'm recovered. We try to visit all the mastecomy patients before they're released to provide information. We include a gift bag with a heart-shaped pillow that's wonderful for the side that had any lymph nodes removed. There's also a temporary prosthesis (nylon case with fiber-fill). We also include a brochure/flyer for the oncology boutique that is in the hospital and has the camisoles, etc. I also tell the ladies to be sure they know how to handle the drain, and if they haven't had a visit from the physical therapist, we can give them information on the exercises. Most mast patients are in and out so quickly these days it can be a challenge to get to them, but if miss them, we try to contact them at home in a few days. I know all hospitals don't have these features, but you can call your area ACS and ask for a Reach to Recovery visit - they'll bring you the same gift bag.   Minz  Minz

Posts.Title: 92 year old Gnovian AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2008 12:32PM MinAZ wrote: I had  wire-guided surgical biopsy for ADH  some time ago, and I was completely out before they even took me out of pre-op. A couple of weeks ago I had a minor surgery on my leg and told them I wanted to be awake and watch (- yes, everyone thinks I'm crazy!) The anesthesiologist told me all the options he could do - I hadn't known there were any choices. I ended up being awake until actually in the OR and on the table - I could look around and talk to the various people in there. Then I had to be asleep while they numbed the leg area and actually did the incision, then I was awake to watch the stitching - and chitchat with the doc!  So talk to your anesthesiologist to make sure he/she knows what you want and that should work out OK for you! Minz
Posts.Title: Are you awake or asleep? snoopygirl karen1956

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 01:31AM MinAZ wrote: Mary - yes, it was the stereotactic procedure. I went to day for a fitting, and the table actually worked OK with the expander, although not very comfortable. BUT - then there was part of the equipment that would not work, so the fitting couldn't be done. They had to call the technicians and the table won't be operational until some time in November!!! I wonder how many of these biopsies are going to be delayed because of that!  My surgeon's nurse got me in next week at another place, but whether they can actually do the biopsy without the fitting remains to be seen.  I'll take my films up there tomorrow and see what they say. And you're right - I'll be glad to get the expander exchanged. If we ever get to that point now!!!! But I have a positive attitude, and I expect the biopsy to be OK, and the exchange to go on as scheduled. (Knock on wood!)
